awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Multi-Scale Experimental Mechanics Education Module
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on combining solid mechanics experimentation and material visualization to enhance undergraduate solid mechanics education and assist students to develop appropriate mental models of abstract engineering concepts to enhance learning.  This effort employs multiple length scale material characterization and visualization for solid mechanics education, web-based education modules, and experiential learning.  A broad impact of this research is a contribution to the education of future professional engineers in fundamental solid mechanics and increase in the critical number of individuals who are capable of translating STEM advances into engineering innovations.

This research project is pilot testing the effectiveness of mechanics education by establishing the relation of material structure and solid mechanics, which can assistant students to understand complex and abstract concepts in engineering.  To understand whether the proposed approach can improve student learning and retention of course materials covered, Primary Trait Analysis, Student Assessment of Learning Gains Surveys, and individual student interviews are being used to analyze and compare students' learning outcomes with conventional methods.  Changes in Student Mental Model Representation are being analyzed through a language-oriented methodology for text and graphical representations of open problems.  Pre- and post-experiments are being used to compare and track changes in students' mental representation. The measures are also being used to compare control and treatment groups.  Students' perceptual and motivational characteristics are being assessed using a multi-scale questionnaire instrument previously designed and validated by project personnel.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this collaborative project is to enhance the conceptual understanding of engineering students of how and why structural and machine components behave and fail the way they do under different loading conditions. By revealing the different phenomena that occur at the different length scales of the material (atomic, micro, and the macroscale/real life scales leading to the observed behavior), much of the theoretical frameworks and abstractions students commonly struggle with are minimized. Using experimental testing and characterization data collected at different length scales of a variety of representative material classes and manufacturing methods, a multi-scale education platform was developed which bridges materials properties, processing, structure and performance. The developed module, which was used in appropriate classes across the collaborating institutions, proved helpful for students to better rationalize materials’ behavior. To circumvent the in-person, in-lab restrictions of COVID-19, the modules were placed online and virtual reality environments were developed to enable students to remotely and virtually perform mechanical testing and imaging, as an alternative. To evaluate the effectiveness of the developed education module, the investigator, along with the help of an independent evaluator, developed assessment tools to measure students’ understanding of fundamental concepts related to solid mechanics, materials, and manufacturing with an overall positive influence. The results of all modules have been presented and published in national conferences and journal articles. Multiple undergraduate and graduate students directly worked on this project and benefited directly from the research but a larger number of undergraduate students benefited from the developed modules, which were used to improve the delivery of solid mechanics concepts in their courses. The collaboration between the University of Oklahoma and Tuskegee University proved successful in developing educational tools to enhance solid mechanics education for minority students. Finally, the project improved the infrastructure at Tuskegee University by providing the funds to procure vat photo-polymerization 3D printer. The printer enabled performing a basic study of the effect of the printing parameters of samples on their tensile behavior. Samples were 3D printed at Tuskegee University and tested at the University of Oklahoma.

In summary, modules created in this project had significant connections to several disciplines, including mechanical design, materials engineering, additive manufacturing, materials characterization, and virtual reality-enhanced learning. The collaborative nature of the project helped establish a national and international community of users. In addition to mechanical testing and characterization-based education modules and products, this project produced multidisciplinary engineering education approaches and products at the University of Oklahoma and Tuskegee University.
